content.question: An aeroplane equipped with reversible flight controls...

options.A: does not have mechanical back-up.
options.B: need not be equipped with a separate gust lock system.
options.C: does not require an artificial feel system.
options.D: does not need trim tabs.

key_points: A reversible flight control system will have aerodynamic forces on the controls, therefore there is no need or an artificial feel system
Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude
The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls
learning.explanation: A reversible flight control system will have aerodynamic forces on the controls, therefore there is no need or an artificial feel system. Primary flight controls Are controls which movement causes a rotation about one of the three axes of the aircraft, causing a change in the aircraft’s flightpath or attitude. The elevator, rudder and ailerons are considered to be the primary flight controls. The primary flight controls in a manually controlled system are reversible. This means that a force applied to the controls is a force which moves the control surface, and also a force which moves the control surface will move the pilot’s controls. This means that the air pressure on the control surface can be felt in the pilot’s controls. When the flight controls are fully power operated this is not the case and is called irreversible. This means that if there is a force moving the control surface this will not move the control columns, and there will be no natural feel on the controls. Because of this there will need to be an artificial feel unit installed in a fully powered or irreversible control system. This artificial feel unit should apply force to the cockpit controls in proportion to the control deflection and in proportion to the aircraft’s speed. The artificial feel system is placed in parallel with the hydraulic actuator, so the movement of the flight controls in the cockpit will cause the hydraulic actuator to operate. During this same movement the artificial feel system will apply pressure on the controls appropriate to the airspeed of the aircraft. This artificial feel system will also work with a trim system, but this works different than a normal trim surface does. A movement of the trimwheel will result in a movement of the electric trim actuator, and so the control surface, but not in the movement of the control column (this is for elevator control). It is different for aileron and rudder trim. Elevator trim: zero force position of the control column does not change (control column/horn/stick does not move) Aileron trim: zero force position changes (control wheel turns in the direction of the trim) Rudder trim: zero force position changes (pedals move in the direction of the trim)

content.question: The Airbus A320 has Fly By Wire flight controls. Imagine manually flying an Airbus A320 at low altitude and low airspeed, at the critical angle of attack. How can the pilots make the aircraft climb?

options.A: By trimming for a nose-up attitude.
options.B: By engaging AP in vertical speed mode.
options.C: Simply by pulling back on the sidestick.
options.D: By moving the thrust levers forward to increase speed.

key_points: Note: We think that the different authorities have different versions of this question
Some mention that it is a Fly By Wire aircraft, some saying Airbus, and some saying specifically A320
It is the same answer for all these, and EASA are usually talking about A320s when they mention Fly By Wire anyway
learning.explanation: Note: We think that the different authorities have different versions of this question. Some mention that it is a Fly By Wire aircraft, some saying Airbus, and some saying specifically A320. It is the same answer for all these, and EASA are usually talking about A320s when they mention Fly By Wire anyway. We think the questions are similar enough to warrant only this one in the bank, but if further feedback says otherwise, we will add separate questions. Fly By Wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. One of the largest benefits of Fly By Wire is the flight envelope protection system. It has many abilities, including preventing excessive bank angles, preventing the stall, overspeed protection, overload protection, etc. This question used to be very ambiguous, but over the past year it has changed a few times, and now we know it is an Airbus (we believe it says A320 in some exam authorities) and it is flying at the critical angle of attack. As it is at its critical angle of attack, pulling back on the sidestick would make it initially attempt to climb, but as this would further increase the angle of attack and slow the aircraft, the flight envelope protections would step in and stop this pitching backwards. Therefore the only thing that can save us from this scenario is actually adding thrust. This will allow us to increase our speed, decreasing our AoA, and subsequently, the flight controls will allow us to begin a climb. This is the only way to induce any sort of climb from the very low energy state of the question. In fact, the Airbus A320 actually has a set of limiting angles of attack, where different measures will be taken one by one to stop an impending stall. One of those measures is automatically applying TO/GA (Take off/Go around) thrust. You are not expected to know this for the question, so do not assume that the aircraft will automatically do this if you keep pulling back. Video Explanation:

content.question: Rudder trim adjustment in an aeroplane with irreversible flight controls is…

options.A: unnecessary because this aeroplane does not need rudder trim.
options.B: an adjustment of the rudder ratio changer.
options.C: an adjustment of the zero force rudder position.
options.D: an adjustment of the rudder trim tab.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.01.03.05: Explain the operating principle of rudder and aileron trim in a fully powered control system. There are two basic types of flight controls, reversible and irreversible. Reversible flight controls are those that have a two way force mechanism naturally as part of the system. This includes manual flight controls, which use levers and pulleys to transfer pilot force to the controls, and partially powered controls, which are aided by hydraulic force, but there is still a mechanical connection between the pilot and controls (think powered steering in a car). The connecting factor is that if you went to the aileron and pushed it, the controls in the cockpit would move accordingly. The opposite are irreversible controls, which have no "backwards force", or "feel". These are only 1 way, so the pilot can move the control surfaces, but the control surfaces cannot move the pilot's controls. Fully powered hydraulic controls and fly-by-wire controls are irreversible. irreversible controls have no natural feedback, so require artificial "feel", so the pilot has something to push against, the controls naturally centre, etc. If you pushed the aileron, the controls would not move. There are pros and cons to both, but one benefit of irreversible controls such as fly by wire, is that trimming can be made easier. All a simple trim system needs to do is adjust where the system considers the "zero" point to be. Therefore the rudder (in this case) will sit naturally at the new "zero" point, which will produce a constant trim in a particular direction. Pitch trim can differ from this method though, and some manufacturers take their own stance on trimming, such as if the rudder pedals are supposed to move with the trim or not, etc.

content.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Fly-By-Wire systems?

options.A: Digital signals are converted into analogue signals by the PCU.
options.B: PCUs are operated by analogue signals.
options.C: Flight controls are connected to control surfaces by direct wire linkages.
options.D: Control wires feed pilot control movements into the PCUs.

key_points: FLY-BY-WIRE SYSTEMS Fly-By-Wire Systems remove the direct linkage from the control wheel to the Power Control Unit (PCU)
A FBW control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
learning.explanation: FLY-BY-WIRE SYSTEMS Fly-By-Wire Systems remove the direct linkage from the control wheel to the Power Control Unit (PCU). A FBW control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These control inputs are sent to the Primary Flight Computer (PFC), which converts the mechanical movements of the control surfaces into a comum electrical output. The Actuator Control Electronics (ACE) takes these electrical signals and converts them into analogue signal which are sent to the Power Control Unit (PCU), the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces.

content.question: What is the concept of control-surface protection by means of a pressure-relief valve?

options.A: A pressure-relief valve is used to resist the aerodynamic loads that are exerted on a flight control surface.
options.B: It is a feature used to increase the aerodynamic lift induced by the control surface.
options.C: It is the method by which a flight control surface can be moved by the pilot.
options.D: A pressure-relief valve provides the automatic retraction of a flight control surface under excessive aerodynamic loads.

key_points: A pressure relief valve will open once the pressure on the valve exceeds a predetermined limit
If an aircraft has high speed or experiences turbulence, the forces on flight controls can get too high and might cause failure or damage
The relief valve is placed for when that happens, if the pressure gets too high the valve will open allowing the surface to retract
learning.explanation: A pressure relief valve will open once the pressure on the valve exceeds a predetermined limit. If an aircraft has high speed or experiences turbulence, the forces on flight controls can get too high and might cause failure or damage. The relief valve is placed for when that happens, if the pressure gets too high the valve will open allowing the surface to retract. The figure in the annex gives an example of a schematic for where this relief valve is placed.

content.question: An aircraft has a fully powered flight control system, linked to a single hydraulic actuator. If this actuator fails, which of the following will happen?

options.A: The control column will become jammed.
options.B: The back-up hydraulic system will be activated.
options.C: The pilot will need to use greater force to manoeuvre the aircraft.
options.D: The control surface will not respond to pilot inputs.

key_points: Fully powered flight controls means that there is no mechanical linkage between the pilot's controls and the control surfaces, but instead, the pilot's control movements command a servo valve which allows hydraulic pressure into the control surface actuators to provide a much larger force to the control surfaces than any pilot would ever be able to produce
There are, however, still some problems with that concept, such as in this question, where redundancy needs to be implemented in case of jammed or broken controls
This is usually done by duplication of actuators, of control runs, hydraulic system backups, multiple control surfaces, etc
learning.explanation: Fully powered flight controls means that there is no mechanical linkage between the pilot's controls and the control surfaces, but instead, the pilot's control movements command a servo valve which allows hydraulic pressure into the control surface actuators to provide a much larger force to the control surfaces than any pilot would ever be able to produce. There are, however, still some problems with that concept, such as in this question, where redundancy needs to be implemented in case of jammed or broken controls. This is usually done by duplication of actuators, of control runs, hydraulic system backups, multiple control surfaces, etc. A hydraulic actuator is a piston in a tube, which is moved by the hydraulic pressure, and mechanically moves the control surface. In this case, the single actuator has failed. If there is no redundancy for this part (which there is not in this scenario), then the control surface will not respond to any of the pilot's movements on the control column. It will be unusable.

content.question: Whilst flying an Airbus fitted with FBW flight controls, you encounter windshear. What should you do with the sidestick? Pull the stick...

options.A: aggressively backwards as windshear is a very dynamic phenomenon which requires full elevator deflection.
options.B: all the way back, and keep it fully back.
options.C: all the way backwards until reaching the stall speed, then use the stick to maintain that attitude only.
options.D: very slowly backwards to avoid stalling.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls
The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals
These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire systems A fly by wire control system is a powered system (irreversible) that uses electronic inputs to a solenoid servo valve instead of mechanical inputs from conventional powered controls. The pilot operates the controls, these can be a sidestick and rudder pedals or a conventional yoke with rudder pedals. These controls are fitted with transducers which convert the mechanical movement into an electrical output which is then amplified and processed by several computers. These computers provide the input for the servo valves which controls the movement of the hydraulic actuators attached to the flight control surfaces. One of the largest benefits of fly by wire is the flight envelope protection system. It has many abilities, including preventing excessive bank angles, preventing the stall, overspeed protection, overload protection, etc. In the event of severe windshear, the recommended way to gain altitude and escape the windshear is to apply maximum thrust and pitch up to a high attitude until reaching near the stall speed, then maintain that speed. In theory, a Fly-By-Wire aircraft can actually perform some of that for the pilot. Because of the stall protection of a Fly-By-Wire flight control system, in theory, the pilot can just apply full thrust and pull back on the sidestick all the way, and just hold it there. The aircraft will go into stall protection mode, which in an Airbus A320 (as EASA usually refer to) changes the control logic slightly above αprot then applies TO/GA thrust above αfloor (the pilot should already have applied TO/GA at this point of course), but will not let the aircraft fully stall, no matter how hard the pilot pulls back. Note: this is not the way an Airbus pilot should actually fly a windshear escape manoeuvre, it is simply a theoretical method of doing so. However, the examiner likes to find interesting ways of testing fly-by-wire knowledge, and that includes asking you about the very limits of the systems.

1. There should be suitable design precautions to prevent flight with the gust lock engaged

content.question:
A large transport aircraft experiences an unusual attitude situation and successfully recovers from a stall.
Which of the following automatic aircraft response may the pilot encounter?

options.A: Automatic deactivation of the autopilot for the remainder of the flight, forcing at least one crew member to monitor the flight path at all times.
options.B: The auto-slat system may extend the slats fully (part of) automatically through a high angle of attack reading received by the stall warning system.
options.C: Inhibited master warning and caution alerts to reduce distraction to the flight crew during stall recovery.
options.D: The auto-thrust may disengage and command idle power preventing excessive pitch-up moments found during a high power setting.

key_points: AUTO-SLAT SYSTEM Some aircrafts are equipped with an Auto-Slat System
This system enhances the airplane stall characteristics
Upon receiving a signal from the stall warning system, the auto-slat system automatically operates the slats, extending them from the midrange position to the fully extended landing position
learning.explanation: AUTO-SLAT SYSTEM Some aircrafts are equipped with an Auto-Slat System. This system enhances the airplane stall characteristics. Upon receiving a signal from the stall warning system, the auto-slat system automatically operates the slats, extending them from the midrange position to the fully extended landing position. The slats retract a few seconds after the signal is removed.

content.question: Which of the following is an advantage of Fly-By-Wire systems and their redundancy?

options.A: Better precision.
options.B: Increased stability.
options.C: Increased damage tolerance.
options.D: Better control feel.

key_points: Fly-By-Wire A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) control system is a fully powered flight control system (irreversible) that uses computers to translate pilot control inputs into movement of the hydraulically powered flight control surfaces
The answer to this question does seem a little counter-intuitive initially, but remember that the question is really asking about the advantages of fly-by-wire aircraft's redundancy elements
As Fly-By-Wire control systems have no manual back-up systems, and flight controls can be lost due to loss of power, loss of computers, loss of hydraulics, etc
learning.explanation: Fly-By-Wire A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) control system is a fully powered flight control system (irreversible) that uses computers to translate pilot control inputs into movement of the hydraulically powered flight control surfaces. The answer to this question does seem a little counter-intuitive initially, but remember that the question is really asking about the advantages of fly-by-wire aircraft's redundancy elements. As Fly-By-Wire control systems have no manual back-up systems, and flight controls can be lost due to loss of power, loss of computers, loss of hydraulics, etc., they have multiple redundant systems to prevent this. In reality, they end up having more redundancy than some simpler systems, in the amount of separate systems that can be used as backups. For this question then, the correct answer is actually that FBW aircraft benefit from increased damage tolerance. Now we strongly believe that it very much depends on the type of damage and its location, but when you consider that FBW aircraft usually have 3 hydraulic systems and 3-4 flight control computers, you can see where the examiner is coming from. That is more redundant systems than simpler aircraft would usually have.

content.question: You are on an approach when extending flaps, due to a malfunction the right flap does not extend. What will happen to the aircraft?

options.A: Plane will bank right and left wing may stall.
options.B: Plane will bank left and right wing may stall.
options.C: Plane will bank right and right wing may stall.
options.D: Plane will go into a spin.

key_points: The extension of the left wing flaps generates an uneven increase in lift compared to the lack of flaps on the right wing
Consequently, the left wing raises, inducing a right bank in the aircraft
Furthermore, any aircraft maneuver that involves a turn leads to an elevation in the load factor
learning.explanation: The extension of the left wing flaps generates an uneven increase in lift compared to the lack of flaps on the right wing. Consequently, the left wing raises, inducing a right bank in the aircraft. Furthermore, any aircraft maneuver that involves a turn leads to an elevation in the load factor. Keep in mind that the stall speed grows proportionally to the square root of the load factor. Thus, in this situation, there is a heightened risk of stalling (and entering a spin) if prompt action is not taken, given the diminishing margin to the stall speed. In all cases of asymmetric flap, the wing with the greater amount of flap extended is producing a substantially higher amount of lift. At the same time, increased drag on the flaps-down side creates a pronounced adverse yaw situation, with the nose swinging toward the wing with most flaps deflected.

content.question: Regarding a trimmable horizontal stabiliser on a large transport aeroplane, the most common basic design is that the horizontal stabiliser…

options.A: Trim is adjusted by control tabs.
options.B: Is moved by hydraulically actuated control tabs.
options.C: Is moved by hydraulically actuated jack.
options.D: Moves in response to lateral control column/stick movements.

key_points: At the rear of the fuselage of most aircraft one finds a horizontal stabilizer and an elevator
The design of the majority of airliners and transport aircraft incorporates a trimmable horizontal stabilizer
The trimmable stabilizer features a fully moving horizontal tail surface
learning.explanation: At the rear of the fuselage of most aircraft one finds a horizontal stabilizer and an elevator. The design of the majority of airliners and transport aircraft incorporates a trimmable horizontal stabilizer. The trimmable stabilizer features a fully moving horizontal tail surface. The trimmable stabilizer does not move in response to control column or control stick movement, instead it can be operated by moving the elevator trim switch. Trimmable horizontal stabilisers are normally moved by hydraulic actuators under either manual or electrical control. The most common type being moved by a hydraulically actuated jack.

content.question: How do auto-slat systems function and what is their main purpose?

options.A: Electrically operated auto-slats are linked to the angle of attack probe and retract only during cruise. Otherwise, they remain extended to prevent icing from forming on the leading edge.
options.B: Spring-powered auto-slats are extended by aerodynamic suction to delay the stalling angle of attack and are retracted by spring force to minimize drag.
options.C: Hydraulically powered auto-slats are extended if the aircraft's angle of attack approaches the stall, in order to delay the stalling angle of attack. They retract when the condition no longer exists to minimise drag.
options.D: Pneumatically operated auto-slats are heated by bleed air to prevent icing on the leading edge. They are operated by the landing gear lever, extending when the gear is selected down and retracting when up is selected.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.05.02.01.08: Describe the function of an auto-slat system. Slats Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings of fixed-wing aircraft which, when deployed, allow the wing to operate at a higher angle of attack. At high angles of attack they allow the air over the wing to have much greater energy, allowing the aircraft to fly at much higher angles of attack without stalling. This allows the wing to produce a higher maximum coefficient of lift, and can therefore fly slower whilst still balancing the weight force with lift. Slats, like flaps, are therefore used for take-off, landing and slow flight, thereby reducing take-off and landing distances. Slats are still retracted for normal flight as they increase drag, similar to flaps. They are hydraulically powered, just like the flaps and other flight controls on large aircraft. Some aircrafts are equipped with an Auto-Slat System. This system enhances the airplane stalling characteristics. Upon receiving a signal from the stall warning system that the aircraft is close to the stall (high AoA), the auto-slat system automatically operates the slats, extending them from the midrange position to the fully extended landing position. The slats retract a few seconds after the signal is removed. This is a bit like a "get out of jail free" card, and allows a few extra degrees angle of attack before the wing completely stalls.

content.question: During level cruising flight, an aeroplane experiences a malfunction of the pressure controller. If the cabin vertical speed indicator reads 200 ft/min rate of descent…

options.A: the aircraft has to climb to a higher flight level in order to reduce the cabin altitude to its initial value.
options.B: the differential pressure will rise to its maximum value, thus causing the safety relief valves to open.
options.C: the crew has to intermittently cut off the incoming air flow in order to maintain a zero cabin altitude.
options.D: a descent must be initiated to prevent the oxygen masks dropping when the cabin altitude reaches 14 000 ft.

key_points: As the cabin vertical speed indicator reads a 200ft/min descent, this means that the pressure in the cabin is increasing
As the pressure is increasing while it shouldn’t, the maximum pressure differential will be exceeded causing the safety relief valves to open
Pressurization System control methods The way the pressure in the aircraft is controlled is by having a constant mass of air entering the cabin through the airconditioning system
learning.explanation: As the cabin vertical speed indicator reads a 200ft/min descent, this means that the pressure in the cabin is increasing. As the pressure is increasing while it shouldn’t, the maximum pressure differential will be exceeded causing the safety relief valves to open. Pressurization System control methods The way the pressure in the aircraft is controlled is by having a constant mass of air entering the cabin through the airconditioning system. This mass of air is kept constant by the mass flow controller. The pressure is regulated by the amount of air which is discharged back to the atmosphere by the outflow valves. So the more open these valves are, the lower the pressure will be in the aircraft. There must be two safety measures in place with these kind of systems to avoid a too high pressure or too low when the outside pressure is higher than that of the cabin. Safety valve This is a mechanical pressure relief valve which should open when the cabin exceeds the maximum pressure differential to which the aircraft is designed. Inward relief valve This valve works the other way around than the safety valve and will open once the pressure outside of the aircraft is higher so there will be no negative pressure differential. These two valves may be combined in the same unit or may be two separate units, but there must be at least two of each installed. Instrumentation The indications needed for a pressurized cabin are: Cabin altimeter, this reads a cabin pressure but it is calibrated in a way that it reads the equivalent in altitude of the cabin Cabin vertical speed Indicator, this indicates the rate at which the cabin altitude is climbing or descending. Cabin Differential Pressure Gauge, indicates the difference in absolute pressure between the inside of the cabin and the pressure outside of the aircraft. In additional to these parameters there should be a visual and aural warning when the cabin exceeds an altitude of 10 000 ft.

content.question: The bleed-air pressure gauge on the flight deck shows the bleed-air pressure relative to…

options.A: cabin pressure.
options.B: pitot pressure.
options.C: a vacuum.
options.D: atmospheric static pressure.

key_points: Bleed-air pressure gauges allow the pilots to monitor bleed air manifold temperature and pressure
This question is effectively asking what reference pressure is the bleed-air pressure compared to
Bleed-air is pressurised air tapped off the engines/APU for either pressurisation, air conditioning, or ice protection
learning.explanation: Bleed-air pressure gauges allow the pilots to monitor bleed air manifold temperature and pressure. This question is effectively asking what reference pressure is the bleed-air pressure compared to. Bleed-air is pressurised air tapped off the engines/APU for either pressurisation, air conditioning, or ice protection. Bleed-air pressure is measured relative to the atmospheric static pressure, this concept is similar to comparing total pressure against static pressure when measuring airspeed.

content.question: When does the pressurization start during the flight?

options.A: When the pressure controller senses that the aircraft is airborne.
options.B: When the altitude of 8000 ft is reached.
options.C: During start-up/taxi.
options.D: During climbout.

key_points: PRE-PRESSURIZATION In general, you want the cabin to be pressurized in flight; and not pressurized on the ground If the system followed only and exactly that logic, at the moment of lift-off, it would start pressurizing immediately, with the goal of overcoming the sudden change in pressure due to the aircraft's rapid climb away from the ground
In practice, that ends up being a pressure "bump" right at (or slightly after) rotation, which is undesirable since it is at least noticeable and potentially uncomfortable

To prevent this pressure "bump", the pressure controller is programmed to slowly pressurize the cabin slightly while the aircraft is still on the ground, so that at lift-off it is essentially maintaining the differential it has, rather than starting pressurization all at once
learning.explanation: PRE-PRESSURIZATION In general, you want the cabin to be pressurized in flight; and not pressurized on the ground If the system followed only and exactly that logic, at the moment of lift-off, it would start pressurizing immediately, with the goal of overcoming the sudden change in pressure due to the aircraft's rapid climb away from the ground. In practice, that ends up being a pressure "bump" right at (or slightly after) rotation, which is undesirable since it is at least noticeable and potentially uncomfortable. To prevent this pressure "bump", the pressure controller is programmed to slowly pressurize the cabin slightly while the aircraft is still on the ground, so that at lift-off it is essentially maintaining the differential it has, rather than starting pressurization all at once.

content.question: An aeroplane with a pressurised cabin is flying at FL310. Following a malfunction of the pressure controller, the outflow valve runs to the open position.What will be the resulting cabin rate of climb indication, cabin pressure altitude, and differential pressure?

options.A: Both cabin rate of climb indication and cabin pressure altitude increase, and differential pressure increases.
options.B: Both cabin rate of climb indication and cabin pressure altitude decrease, and differential pressure increases.
options.C: Cabin rate of climb indication decreases, cabin pressure altitude increases, and differential pressure decreases.
options.D: Both cabin rate of climb indication and cabin pressure altitude increase, and differential pressure decreases.

key_points: As the outflow valves runs to the open position, the pressure in the cabin will drop
A lower pressure means a higher cabin altitude
So when the pressure starts to decrease the rate of climb will increase as well as the cabin pressure altitude
learning.explanation: As the outflow valves runs to the open position, the pressure in the cabin will drop. A lower pressure means a higher cabin altitude. So when the pressure starts to decrease the rate of climb will increase as well as the cabin pressure altitude. As the differential pressure is the difference between the cabin pressure and that of the ambient pressure around the aircraft this will decrease. Pressurization System control methods The way the pressure in the aircraft is controlled is by having a constant mass of air entering the cabin through the airconditioning system. This mass of air is kept constant by the mass flow controller. The pressure is regulated by the amount of air which is discharged back to the atmosphere by the outflow valves. So the more open these valves are, the lower the pressure will be in the aircraft. There must be two safety measures in place with these kind of systems to avoid a too high pressure or too low when the outside pressure is higher than that of the cabin. Safety valve This is a mechanical pressure relief valve which should open when the cabin exceeds the maximum pressure differential to which the aircraft is designed. Inward relief valve This valve works the other way around than the safety valve and will open once the pressure outside of the aircraft is higher so there will be no negative pressure differential. key_points: Most jet aircraft have pneumatic systems with 2 separate air conditioning packs

These usually use bleed air that has been taken from that side engine's compressor, thereby having a left pack which runs from left engine bleed air, and a right pack which runs off air from the right hand engine(s)
The APU also feeds bleed air into the pneumatic system (usually to the left side)
learning.explanation: Most jet aircraft have pneumatic systems with 2 separate air conditioning packs. These usually use bleed air that has been taken from that side engine's compressor, thereby having a left pack which runs from left engine bleed air, and a right pack which runs off air from the right hand engine(s). The APU also feeds bleed air into the pneumatic system (usually to the left side). In the air, the system should operate normally with no interaction between the left and right side. There is an isolation valve between the two systems to either make them interconnected or completely separate. This is usually open on the ground when the engines are off to provide APU bleed air to both packs for cooling and to both engines for starting. It is closed in the air for split operation, unless an abnormal situation occurs, such as a loss of engine bleed air, pack failure, etc., when the isolation valve will either automatically be opened or the flight crew will open it to balance the load within the system. A significant pressure difference between the two sides of an isolation valve in the air is likely to mean that one of the sides has an issue that the other does not have. In the case of the Boeing 737 specifically (image shown above), the isolation valve opens automatically if any of the pack or engine bleed switches are NOT in their normal locations (bleeds on, packs auto) as the system knows that the pneumatics will become unbalanced in that case (bleed off, pack off, or pack set to high flow, etc.). It can be manually forced open or closed though by positioning the switch each side of the "AUTO" position. It is not good to feed bleed air into a leaky duct, though, so that is something to be careful of with pressure differentials. As for the other options: "They close when the system pressure equals the environmental pressure." This is talking roughly about the pressurisation outflow valve. That is what controls the pressure in the cabin. "They open when there is a leak in one of the systems." This is a bad thing, as we do not want to feed hot bleed air into a leaky air duct, due to overheating and potential loss of pressurisation. "They close when the engines are at maximum thrust." Engines at high thrust produce more bleed air, but they will produce it to both sides of the pneumatic manifold, so isolation valve open or closed, it shouldn't make too much difference.

learning.explanation: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air. Often referred to as "air conditioning packs". In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger. The bleed air is then compressed in the compressor section and is then fed through to the secondary heat exchanger to remove as much heat as possible before being expanded and introduced to the turbine section which is used to drive the compressor. learning.explanation: Most jet aircraft have pneumatic systems with 2 separate air conditioning packs. These usually use bleed air that has been taken from that side engine's compressor, thereby having a left pack which runs from left engine bleed air, and a right pack which runs off air from the right hand engine(s). The APU also feeds bleed air into the pneumatic system (usually to the left side). In the air, the system should operate normally with no interaction between the left and right side. There is an isolation valve between the two systems to either make them interconnected or completely separate. This is usually open on the ground to provide APU bleed air to both packs for cooling and to both engines for starting. It is closed in the air for split operation, unless an abnormal situation occurs, such as a loss of engine bleed air, pack failure, etc., when the isolation valve will either automatically be opened or the flight crew will open it to balance the load within the system.

options.B: Air from the turbine of the turbocharger.
options.C: Ram air and an electric fan.
options.D: A vapour-cycle machine is a closed system, therefore a separate air source is not required.

key_points: The absence of a bleed air source on a reciprocrating engine aircraft makes the use of an Air Cycle system impractical for conditioning cabin air
Vapour Cycle air is used on most nonturbine aircraft that are equipped with air conditioning
However, it is not a source of pressurising air
learning.explanation: The absence of a bleed air source on a reciprocrating engine aircraft makes the use of an Air Cycle system impractical for conditioning cabin air. Vapour Cycle air is used on most nonturbine aircraft that are equipped with air conditioning. However, it is not a source of pressurising air. The vapour cycle system only cools the cabin. It differs from the other systems in that the cooling of the charge air is mainly achieved by a refrigerant. "Air from the turbine of the turbocharger" is incorrect because the air from the turbine is already highly compressed and hot, which makes it unsuitable for the intended purpose. "Ram air and an electric fan" is incorrect as the vapor-cycle system does not operate using ram air or an electric fan for its cooling process. "A vapour-cycle machine is a closed system, therefore a separate air source is not required." is incorrect because a vapor-cycle system necessitates an external source of high-pressure and high-temperature air to facilitate the cooling of the refrigerant and other components. Note: we have recently updated the correct option for this question based on recent feedback. Please let us know if you come across this question in your official exam.

learning.explanation: REFRIGERANT For many years, dichlorodifluoromethane (under the brand name Freon-12/R12) was the standard refrigerant used in aircraft vapor cycle air conditioning systems. Some of these systems remain in use today. R12 was found to have a negative effect on the environment; in particular, it degraded the earth’s protective ozone layer. In most cases, it has been replaced by tetrafluoroethane (R134a), which is safer for the environment. Regardless of manufacturer, refrigerants are sometimes called Freon, which is a trade name owned by the Dupont Company.

learning.explanation: This question is not brilliant because the cabin vertical speed is indicated on the cabin vertical speed indicator, but the examiner seemingly doesn't want to make the question that easy, and seen as the cabin VSI is often located in the same place as the cabin altimeter and other pressurisation gauges, that is why this answer is most correct, particularly against the other options. Pressurisation As modern aircraft operate more efficiently at high altitudes, it is necessary to pressurise the cabin to allow the crew and passengers to function normally without the need for additional oxygen. Up to an altitude of 10 000 ft, the air pressure is sufficient for humans to operate without any issues. Above this altitude the lack of oxygen can become an issue for the performance of the crew and the wellbeing of the passengers. Most commercial air transport aircraft have the cabin pressurized to an equivalent of 8000 ft or less. Because the pressurization of the aircraft it is also possible to perform high rates of descent while the change in pressure in the cabin is a lot lower. Cabin rates of climb and descent should be monitored and should normally not exceed 500 ft/min for the climb and 300 ft/min for the descent. Instrumentation The indications needed for a pressurised cabin are: Cabin Altimeter, this reads a cabin pressure but it is calibrated in a way that it reads the equivalent in altitude of the cabin Cabin Vertical Speed Indicator, this indicates the rate at which the cabin altitude is climbing or descending. Cabin Differential Pressure Gauge, indicates the difference in absolute pressure between the inside of the cabin and the pressure outside of the aircraft. These gauges are often combined in some way to take up less space and be easier to read by pilots. In additional to these parameters there should be a visual and aural warning when the cabin exceeds an altitude of 10 000 ft.

key_points: PRESSURIZATION SYSTEMS The aim of a cabin pressurization system is to maintain the cabin altitude at an optimum pressure, irrespective of the height at which the aircraft is flying

learning.explanation: PRESSURIZATION SYSTEMS The aim of a cabin pressurization system is to maintain the cabin altitude at an optimum pressure, irrespective of the height at which the aircraft is flying. For aircraft with passenger cabins, the maximum cabin altitude of an aircraft must be limited to between 6000 and 8000 ft. At this altitude, the air will provide sufficient oxygen for normal use. Cabin Differential Pressure. Cabin pressure - ambient air pressure The difference in pressure between the cabin pressure and the ambient pressure (the pressure in the area immediately surrounding the aircraft). Flying an aircraft at high altitude, with the cabin pressure set to a lower altitude, results in a pressure difference acting on the structure of the aircraft fuselage (hoop stresses). The maximum permissible cabin differential pressure for a transport aircraft is generally between 7 and 9 psi, however it may vary based on the fuselage design strength, and will limit the aircraft’s operational ceiling and its associated maximum cabin altitude. Control. Achieved by feeding air into the cabin (through air conditioning packs) and restricting its flow out - by using electric motor-operated outflow valves. The valves are automatically controlled by the aircraft’s pressurization system when in automatic control. If a higher pressure is needed inside the cabin, the outflow is reduced by closing the outflow valves (which increases the pressure); To reduce cabin pressure, the outflow valve slowly opens, allowing more air to escape.

options.A: ensure an adequate temperature drop in the secondary heat exchanger.

key_points: Refer to the figure What the answer to this question is looking for is that because the pressure and temperature rises across the compressor, there will be a higher difference in temperature between the compressed air and the charge air flowing around the secondary heat exchanger making it more efficient
A bootstrap system is based on a compressor driven by a turbine which is in turn driven by the charge air
In a bootstrap air cycle machine air is tapped from the low pressure compressor of the engine
learning.explanation: Refer to the figure What the answer to this question is looking for is that because the pressure and temperature rises across the compressor, there will be a higher difference in temperature between the compressed air and the charge air flowing around the secondary heat exchanger making it more efficient. A bootstrap system is based on a compressor driven by a turbine which is in turn driven by the charge air. In a bootstrap air cycle machine air is tapped from the low pressure compressor of the engine. This air is then precooled by the primary heat exchanger after which it will pass through the compressor. This will increase pressure and temperature, increasing the pressure will make the energy conversion later in the turbine more efficient. After the compressor the air passes through the secondary heat exchanger to remove the excess heat caused by the compressor. The main temperature reduction is achieved in the heat exchangers. The goal of this system is to be able to use air from only the low pressure compressor. With the compressor in place there will be a sufficiently high pressure drop through the turbine.

key_points: Learning Objective 021
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 021.06.01.01.01: Describe the following means of supplying air for the pneumatic systems for piston-engine aircraft: compressor; vacuum pump. In piston engine aircraft, different sources of air supply can be used, such as compressors, blowers or vacuum pumps. Those devices are driven by small electrical motors or directly by the engine and provide air for some instruments, de-icing and cabin. Compressors are able to handle more air while blowers and vacuum systems are used for lower demands. Ram air turbine may be used on larger aircraft as a backup hydraulic power source. Bleed air provides air supply for a gas turbine engine. Turbocharger is not necessarily running all the time and therefore would be of no use as air supply. Note: Superchargers can be used to provide pneumatic pressure, as they are effectively the same thing as an air compressor, just one that is usually used to provide extra Manifold Pressure to the engine intake air. This is why some textbooks and questions do refer to them as possible pneumatic pressure sources, but compressor pump is much more correct than turbocharger here, as turbochargers are not always working in an engine.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
An aircraft cruising level is FL380. What altitude should the aircraft's cabin be to maintain a differential pressure of 8.17 psi?

key_points: "Cabin pressure differential" is the actual pressure difference between the inside and the outside of the pressurized cabin of the aircraft
Locate the value of 38 000 ft in the first column on the left => continue horizontally to the right and read the corresponding pressure 2
99 PSI
learning.explanation: "Cabin pressure differential" is the actual pressure difference between the inside and the outside of the pressurized cabin of the aircraft. Locate the value of 38 000 ft in the first column on the left => continue horizontally to the right and read the corresponding pressure 2.99 PSI. The maximum allowed pressure differential is 8.17 PSI - that means that the cabin pressure is "outside air pressure (2.99) + differential pressure (8.17)= 11.16 PSI" Cabin altitude corresponding to 11.16 psi is found by interpolating 7000-8000 ft and 11.34-10.92 PSI. For the 0.42 PSI change between 11.34 PSI (7000 ft) and 10.92 (8000 ft) PSI, the change in altitude is 1000 ft in total. So each 0.01 PSI change causes a change in altitude of 23.81 ft. We can calculate 11.16 PSI cabin pressure based on 11.34 PSI or 10.92 PSI. Let's base it on 11.34 PSI. The difference between this and the cabin pressure we calculated is 0.18 (11.34 - 11.16) PSI. Since every 0.01 PSI change causes a change in altitude of 23.81 ft, a change of 0.18 PSI causes an altitude change of 429 ft (23.81 x 18). If we add this value to our base altitude (7000 ft), the result is 7429 ft. (We added it because the altitude increases as the PSI decreases) The closest answer is 7430 ft.

content.question: The main function of an air cycle machine is to...

options.A: cool the bleed air.
options.B: decrease the pressure of the bleed air.
options.C: remove the water from the bleed air.
options.D: pump the conditioned air into the cabin.

key_points: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air
Often referred to as "air conditioning packs"
In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger
learning.explanation: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air. Often referred to as "air conditioning packs". In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger. The bleed air is then compressed in the compressor section and is then fed through to the secondary heat exchanger to remove as much heat as possible before being expanded and introduced to the turbine section which is used to drive the compressor. After passing through the turbine section, the air is then ducted through a water separator to remove excess moisture from the conditioned air before it enters the cabin and cockpit via a one way check valve. Finally, the air passes through a humidifier to increase the moisture content of the conditioning air. Note: Both temperature and pressure decrease when passing through the Air Cycle Machine. However, the main function of an air cycle machine is to cool the bleed air.

learning.explanation: This is sneaky, they are asking about the indication in the cabin of a bleed air duct leak. Therefore, the usual (and very easy) answer of the bleed air duct leak indicator light is no longer correct, because there is no such light in the cabin, only in the flight deck. The bleed air in the pneumatic system is usually fed from a "bleed air source" in a gas turbine engine, which is effectively just air that has already gone through some of the compressor stages and is siphoned off to pressurise the system (not burnt). It is then distributed through pipes to the various parts of the aircraft where it is needed, such as the air conditioning packs or the leading edges of the wings and tailplane for de/anti-icing. The bleed air is very hot (a temperature of 400°C is sometimes quoted, for context) and so any leaks of these pipes could be harmful to the passengers or the other aircraft equipment. Thankfully, it is usually kept far away from passengers, for just this reason, so the first sign of a duct leak in the cabin would likely be reduction in airflow coming through the vents. This is because less air is fed into the air conditioning packs (as some of it has leaked out), so less air is able to be cooled and sent to the cabin vents. The cabin pressure will not drop rapidly as the loss of pressurisation is small, depending on the location of the duct leak, and the outflow valve will close naturally to keep the remaining pressure inside. It could be argued that the cabin temperature could rise above normal limits, but this is highly dependent on the location of the leak. The majority of the bleed air lines exist in the wings and underbelly of the aircraft (mostly unpressurised areas) so the chance of the passenger cabin being heated by this is quite slim, but some aircraft equipment could certainly be damaged.

Cabin pressure - ambient air pressure The difference in pressure between the cabin pressure and the ambient pressure (the pressure in the area immediately surrounding the aircraft). Flying an aircraft at high altitude, with the cabin pressure set to a lower altitude, results in a pressure difference acting on the structure of the aircraft fuselage (hoop stresses). The maximum permissible cabin differential pressure for a transport aircraft is generally between 7 an 9 psi, however it may vary based on the fuselage design strength, and will limit the aircraft’s operational ceiling and its associated maximum cabin altitude. key_points: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air
Often referred to as "air conditioning packs"
In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger
learning.explanation: AIR CYCLE MACHINE Air Cycle Machines are ideally suited for turbine aircraft due to the supply of already compressed bleed air. Often referred to as "air conditioning packs". In Air Cycle Machines, high-pressure bleed air from the engines is first pre-cooled in the primary heat exchanger. The bleed air is then compressed in the compressor section and is then fed through to the secondary heat exchanger to remove as much heat as possible before being expanded and introduced to the turbine section which is used to drive the compressor. After passing through the turbine section, the air is then ducted through a water separator to remove excess moisture from the conditioned air before it enters the cabin and cockpit via a one way check valve. Finally, the air passes through a humidifier to increase the moisture content of the conditioning air.

Anti-icing equipment prevents the formation of ice, while de-icing equipment removes ice after it has formed. Aircraft components that must be protected from ice accumulations include the leading edges of wing and tail surfaces, pitot and static source openings, fuel tank vents, stall warning sensors, windshields, and propeller blades. Additionally, engines can require alternate sources of intake air or ice protected inlets. WINDSHIELD ICE CONTROL. To prevent ice formation, most windshields are electrically heated: small wires or electrically conductive materials are embedded in the windshield or in a panel of glass installed over the exterior of the windshield. By passing electric current through the windshield or panel, sufficient heat is produced to prevent ice formation. OTHER ICE CONTROL SYSTEMS. The pitot tube and static port openings, fuel vents and stall warning sensors, typically contain electrical elements to prevent ice formation. learning.explanation: ICE CONTROL SYSTEMS Two major categories of ice control systems are pneumatic boots – which expand and break ice off aerofoils; and thermal systems – which use bleed air or electricity to heat protected surfaces and prevent ice. Thermal anti-ice systems Thermal anti-ice systems heat the surfaces on aeroplanes to prevent ice formation. Hot air anti-ice systems are installed on some turbojet and turboprop aeroplanes. This is because a turbine engine has a ready source of hot air that can be used to heat aerofoil leading edges. In this system, air is diverted “bled” from one of the later stages of the compressor section of the engine and piped through ducts to the leading edges of the aerofoil to be protected. Engine inlets can also be protected with hot bleed air, or can be electrically heated. When comparing thermal systems to pneumatic boots, thermal systems have the advantage of not disrupting the airflow over the leading edge (when pneumatic boots are inflated, the airflow is modified). However, when using these systems, aircraft performance and maximum thrust will be reduced, since bleed air is extracted from the engine.

learning.explanation: There are 2 different types of ice protection systems, de-icing systems and anti-icing systems. They are quite simple to remember, de-icing is the process of getting rid of the ice that has already formed, whereas anti-icing is preventing the ice from forming at all. The different parts of the aircraft that require ice protection are the wing leading edges, the tail leading edges, any probes or vanes, the windscreen, the engine inlets and the propellers (if fitted). All these components can be de-iced when ice is detected, except for the engines, which have to be anti-iced, as any ice build up could fall into the engine when dislodged and potentially cause a flame out or even damage. On some airframes it is better to anti-ice the wing leading edges aswell, especially if using a weeping wing design like on many light aircraft. Anti-ice systems in turbine-type engines often use engine bleed air to prevent ice formation by heating or otherwise managing the temperature of critical components to ensure safe and efficient engine operation.

learning.explanation: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge. The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges. In flight under normal conditions, the holes remain open and, consequently, the pressure differential is zero. In icing conditions, holes in the leading edge rapidly become blocked by ice. This causes a change in the pressure differential - a decrease in dynamic pressure is sensed, causing the relay unit to give a warning. A heater element is fitted around the tube to dissipate accumulated ice, which heats up the small holes first causing the indications to turn off.

Aircraft components that must be protected from ice accumulations include the leading edges of wing and tail surfaces, pitot and static source openings, fuel tank vents, stall warning sensors, windshields, and propeller blades. Additionally, engines can require alternate sources of intake air or ice protected inlets. The pitot tube and static port openings, fuel vents and stall warning sensors, typically contain electrical elements to prevent ice accretion that can be checked during a pre-flight inspection by touching each component when the heat is on. Note: Whilst it is a requirements that all IFR certified aircraft have pitot tubes fitted with electrical heating elements, having heated static ports is not a requirement.

key_points: ICE CONTROL SYSTEMS Two major categories of ice control systems are pneumatic boots – which expand and break ice off aerofoils; and thermal systems – which use bleed air or electricity to heat protected surfaces and prevent ice
AEROFOIL ICE CONTROL To protect wing and tail surface leading edges from icing, most aeroplanes use pneumatic devices

learning.explanation: ICE CONTROL SYSTEMS Two major categories of ice control systems are pneumatic boots – which expand and break ice off aerofoils; and thermal systems – which use bleed air or electricity to heat protected surfaces and prevent ice. AEROFOIL ICE CONTROL To protect wing and tail surface leading edges from icing, most aeroplanes use pneumatic devices. On many reciprocating-engine and turboprop airplanes, de-icing boots are pneumatically inflated to break the ice, which allows it to be carried away by the airstream. In another system, primarily used by turbine-powered aeroplanes, heated air is directed through ducting in the aerofoil leading edge, to thermally prevent ice from forming. This is referred to as thermal anti-ice system. Thermal Anti-ice Systems Thermal anti-ice systems heat the surfaces on aeroplanes to prevent ice formation. Hot air anti-ice systems are installed on some turbojet and turboprop aeroplanes. This is because a turbine engine has a ready source of hot air that can be used to heat aerofoil leading edges. In this system, air is diverted “bled” from one of the later stages of the compressor section of the engine and piped through ducts to the leading edges of the aerofoil to be protected. Engine inlets can also be protected with hot bleed air, or can be electrically heated.

learning.explanation: There are 2 different types of ice protection systems, de-icing systems and anti-icing systems. They are quite simple to remember, de-icing is the process of getting rid of the ice that has already formed, whereas anti-icing is preventing the ice from forming at all. The different parts of the aircraft that require ice protection are the wing leading edges, the tail leading edges, any probes or vanes, the windscreen, the engine inlets and the propellers (if fitted). All these components can be de-iced when ice is detected, except for the engines, which have to be anti-iced, as any ice build up could fall into the engine when dislodged and potentially cause a flame out or even damage. On some airframes it is better to anti-ice the wing leading edges aswell, especially if using a weeping wing design like on many light aircraft. As for this question, the answers beginning with "prevents" are correct (anti-icing rather than de-icing), and the ice does not form on the trailing edge of a wing (it can flow over the trailing edge in extreme cases but does not "form" there), so therefore the correct answer has to be that it "prevents the formation of ice on engine inlets."

options.B: No. The eye reference position has nothing to do with ice detection.

Learning Objective 021.07.02.01.02: Describe the principle of operation of ice warning systems. Some aircraft are fitted with ice detection systems which show the pilots a warning when ice acccumulation has been detected, often on a small probe. Some aircraft rely simply on visual references, such as the buildup of ice on the windshield wipers, or other items within view of the pilots. This is a design consideration of the aircraft, and the pilots must be able to see indications of ice accretion as they occur, particularly in large jet aircraft where the pilot cannot see the wing easily. As the ice warning is a design consideration, the indications of icing should be visible when the pilot has the correct eye reference position. key_points: Compressed air is taken from the HP compressor stage of a gas turbine engine and is used for various purposes: de/anti-icing, air conditioning, engine start
This compressed air driven from the compressor is known as bleed air
When selecting the bleed air ‘ON’ some of the air will be sucked out of the normal flow inside the engine and will induce some inconveniences and risks
learning.explanation: Compressed air is taken from the HP compressor stage of a gas turbine engine and is used for various purposes: de/anti-icing, air conditioning, engine start. This compressed air driven from the compressor is known as bleed air. When selecting the bleed air ‘ON’ some of the air will be sucked out of the normal flow inside the engine and will induce some inconveniences and risks. In fact, the mass flow of air will be reduced, which will increase the engine’s overall temperature, especially the turbine temperature since less air is available for cooling. It also increases specific fuel consumption and the EGT and the power output (or thrust) will be decreased, in other words, aircraft, and more precisely engine performance will greatly be decreased. Because of all this, it is normal to see PACKS OFF take-off, since all the available power is needed during this critical stage of the flight. Conducting a PACKS OFF take-off also has the advantage of reducing the required thrust and the noise footprint.

key_points: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge
The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges
In flight under normal conditions, the holes remain open and, consequently, the pressure differential is zero
learning.explanation: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge. The detector monitors pressure differential between the two edges. In flight under normal conditions, the holes remain open and, consequently, the pressure differential is zero. In icing conditions, holes in the leading edge rapidly become blocked by ice. This causes a change in the pressure differential - a decrease in dynamic pressure is sensed, causing the relay unit to give a warning. A heater element is fitted around the tube to dissipate accumulated ice, which heats up the small holes first causing the indications to turn off.

learning.explanation: Primary Automatic The ice detector is part of an automated ice protection system. Using signals from the ice detector, the system automatically activates aircraft ice protection systems when needed. An automatic system improves fuel efficiency and reduces wear on moving parts. learning.explanation: FLUID ANTI-ICE SYSTEMS Before flight into icing conditions, ground personnel often spray liquid chemical solutions on aeroplanes to remove ice and to temporarily prevent new ice from forming. Applying similar liquids to airframe surfaces in flight can have comparable benefits. These systems are usually called weeping wings and typically protect wings, tail surfaces, propellers and windshields. Modern systems use leading edge panels that are either laser drilled with thousands of small holes, or fitted with fine stainless steel mesh. In operation, a pump forces a mixture of ethylene glycol, isopropyl alcohol, and water through the holes. This fluid runs back over the surface, forming a thin liquid film that prevents structural ice from forming. The anti-icing fluid is stored in a reservoir that holds enough fluid to provide two or more hours of ice protection when flying in moderate icing conditions.

learning.explanation: SMITHS ICE DETECTOR The Smiths ice detector (also known as a differential pressure ice accretion detector) consists of a hollow tube which contains a series of small holes and one large hole positioned in its leading edge and a separate series in its trailing edge. key_points: We require some specific characteristics for jet fuel

learning.explanation: We require some specific characteristics for jet fuel. We need it to have a low freezing point, so the fuel does not freeze in the tanks when at cruising level with a very low outside air temperature. We also require a flash point high enough that the fuel will not be able to burn on the ground, whilst refuelling etc. Jet A has a freezing point of -40°C Jet A1 is very similar but with some additives, to make the freezing point -47°C, which is slightly better. Jet B is much rarer, but is used for aircraft that operate in very cold climates, and has a freezing point of -60°C. Jet B has a lower freezing point, but also a lower flash point, meaning that it could set on fire if lit at normal ground temperatures. This is why it is known as a "wide cut fuel", and it is not approved for commercial air transport in the EU. Jet A and Jet A1 have a minimum flash point of 38°C, which means that they are not too likely to be flammable during refuelling, etc.

content.question: A four-engined jet transport aircraft experiences an engine failure, but there is no immediate need to land and the aircraft is at a safe altitude and airspeed. Which of the following safety measures could be considered?

options.B: Switch all fuel pumps on to avoid fuel starvation to any remaining three engines.
options.C: Reduce altitude to increase the efficiency of the remaining engines and decrease the fuel burn.
options.D: Increase airspeed to compensate for the loss of thrust and maintain stability.

key_points: Engine failures are not always emergency situations
In a 4-engine aircraft, the loss of one engine means you now have a little thrust assymetry and 75% of the aircraft's maximum thrust avialable
If at cruising level, this might not be enough to maintain altitude, and a drift-down procedure may be required
learning.explanation: Engine failures are not always emergency situations. In a 4-engine aircraft, the loss of one engine means you now have a little thrust assymetry and 75% of the aircraft's maximum thrust avialable. If at cruising level, this might not be enough to maintain altitude, and a drift-down procedure may be required. Remember that this is a lot less bad than losing one engine out of two. One thing to think about is that the right hand engines are usually fed from the right hand wing tanks, and the left hand engines from the left wing tanks. If an engine fails and the aircraft is not going to land immediately, then it is a good idea to make sure all available fuel pumps are on and open up the crossfeed valve (if available) to make sure that the engines all have access to fuel, and that one tank does not run dry before the others. This also helps to keep the aircraft balanced. None of the other options are really necessary in the situation, and descending would make the engines less fuel efficient (though would allow for higher thrust output).

The sealed skin and structural members provide the highest volume of space available with the lowest weight => this is otherwise unused space inside the wings. Aircraft with integral fuel tanks in the wings are said to have wet wings. RIGID TANKS: A rigid tank is a sealed metal container strapped into a compartment designed to accomodate the tank in the airframe structure. They are simple and may be removed for inspection, replacement, or repair. However, this type of tank adds extra weight. FLEXIBLE TANKS/FUEL BLADDERS: Flexible tanks are reinforced rubberized bags installed in a section of the aircraft structure designed to accommodate the weight of the fuel. A bladder tank contains most of the features and components of a rigid tank but does not require as large an opening in the aircraft skin to install. It is rolled up and installed into the compartment through the fuel filler neck or access panel, and is secured by means of metal buttons or snaps inside the compartment. One major down-side to this type of tank is the tendency for materials to work harden through extensive use making them brittle causing cracks.

Complete the following statement:

options.A: The density variation of the fuel.
options.B: The dielectric change between fuel and air.
options.C: The electrical resistance change.
options.D: The resistivity variation of the fuel.

key_points: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric
The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air
The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge
learning.explanation: CAPACITANCE TYPE FUEL GAUGING SYSTEM The working principle of a capacitance-type fuel gauging system is based on the variation of the capacitor’s dielectric. The dielectric is the solution found between the two plates of the capacitor, so in our system, they are the fuel and the air. The plates of the capacitor can hold only a certain amount of electric charge. This amount depends on the distance between the two plates, the area of the plates and the insulating properties of the dielectric. As you can imagine, the area of the plates and the distance between is not going to change over time, they’re fixed. So, the only variable is going to be the dielectric. Therefore, the amount of fuel and air between the plates, which is continuously changing as fuel is consumed, controls the quantity indication.

key_points: Whilst piston aero-engines have historically been petrol engines (gasoline), and therefore can run on various grades of AVGAS (aviation gasoline), or sometimes even MOGAS (motor gasoline), in recent years, aircraft manufacturers have begun using diesel powered piston engines more, primarily due to their much higher fuel efficiency and their steady increase in reliability over the last 20-30 years

learning.explanation: Whilst piston aero-engines have historically been petrol engines (gasoline), and therefore can run on various grades of AVGAS (aviation gasoline), or sometimes even MOGAS (motor gasoline), in recent years, aircraft manufacturers have begun using diesel powered piston engines more, primarily due to their much higher fuel efficiency and their steady increase in reliability over the last 20-30 years. Diesel aero-engines can obviously run on diesel, but actually, more preferred is to run them on standard jet fuel, of which the benchmark fuel type is certainly Jet A-1. Jet fuel is kerosene based, and is very similar to diesel fuel in many ways, but lacks the same lubricating effect of motor diesel, so the diesel piston engines are specially modified or developed to remove this issue. key_points: This is a simple question

For a gravity fed fuel system to work, there is no pump needed to get the fuel to the engine from the tanks (booster pumps are often fitted for use during critical phases of flight), so the fuel is pressurised and fed from the tank(s) to the engine by gravity

learning.explanation: This is a simple question. For a gravity fed fuel system to work, there is no pump needed to get the fuel to the engine from the tanks (booster pumps are often fitted for use during critical phases of flight), so the fuel is pressurised and fed from the tank(s) to the engine by gravity. The fuel must therefore be stored above the carburettor and engine, such as in a high wing aircraft like a Cessna 152. The weight of fuel on the rest of the fuel in the lines is what pushes it through the lines into the carburettor (for a carburetted engine). If the engine was injected, a high pressure pump would be required before the injector to provide the injection pressure, but the system could still be “gravity fed”.

Which of these statements are correct or incorrect?
1. In a piston engine, the fuel supply must be gravity-fed fuel
2. In gas turbine engines, fuel tanks must be in low wing configuration

options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.

key_points: In a piston engine, the fuel supply must be gravity-fed fuel
- incorrect In piston-engine aircraft, fuel can be supplied to the engine through either gravity-fed or pump-fed systems
learning.explanation: 1. In a piston engine, the fuel supply must be gravity-fed fuel. - incorrect In piston-engine aircraft, fuel can be supplied to the engine through either gravity-fed or pump-fed systems. Gravity-fed fuel systems are typically found in high-wing aircraft, where the fuel tanks are positioned above the engine. Gravity allows the fuel to flow naturally from the tanks to the engine without the need for fuel pumps. However, many piston-engine aircraft, especially those with low-wing configurations, use fuel pumps because the fuel tanks are located below the engine. In these cases, mechanical or electric fuel pumps are essential to supply fuel to the engine. Therefore, it is not mandatory for piston-engine fuel supplies to be gravity-fed; the fuel supply method depends on the aircraft's design. 2. In gas turbine engines, fuel tanks must be in low wing configuration. - incorrect Gas turbine engine aircraft can have fuel tanks in various configurations, not exclusively in low-wing designs. While many jet aircraft feature low-wing configurations with fuel tanks integrated into the wings, there are numerous exceptions. High-wing aircraft, such as some turboprop and cargo planes (e.g., the C-130 Hercules), also use gas turbine engines and have fuel tanks located in the wings or fuselage. The placement of fuel tanks in gas turbine engine aircraft is determined by factors like aircraft size, purpose, and design requirements—not solely by the engine type. Therefore, it is not a necessity for gas turbine engine fuel tanks to be in a low-wing configuration.
